content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays several pieces of tissue. I can clearly identify at least three large, ovoid structures with dense basophilic (purple) staining, which are characteristic of lymph nodes. There are also smaller fragments of adipose (fatty) tissue and other connective tissues. The lymph node on the far left appears to have an irregular staining pattern, with some paler areas mixed with the dark purple, suggesting a potential architectural abnormality.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into the largest lymph node on the slide, located on the left. The specific area of interest is at the periphery of the node, just under the capsule. At low power, this region shows a focal area with a different texture and lighter staining compared to the surrounding dense lymphoid tissue. Such an area is highly suspicious for a metastatic deposit, as cancer cells often first seed the subcapsular sinus of a lymph node. It's crucial to examine any such architectural or cytological alteration at high magnification to rule metastasis in or out. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is part of the largest and most abnormal-appearing lymph node on the slide (the first prominent node from the left). At low power, the normal architecture of this node is effaced by pale, infiltrative-looking regions, which is a classic sign of metastasis. My goal is to examine these suspicious areas at high magnification to confirm the presence of non-lymphoid, malignant cells (i.e., carcinoma) and thereby classify this node as positive. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task for these tissue sections is to identify any lymph node metastasis, which is critical for staging the colorectal cancer. The green box is centered on the second large lymph node from the left. I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic examination of every lymph node provided. The goal is to scrutinize the node's architecture, particularly the subcapsular sinus and the parenchyma, for any clusters of atypical epithelial cells that would indicate metastatic carcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining each lymph node for evidence of metastasis. I am zooming into this specific area, which corresponds to the third and smallest of the main lymph nodes, because it appears entirely replaced by abnormal cellular infiltrates. The normal sinusoids and follicular structures are not discernible at low power, raising a strong suspicion of complete effacement by tumor, which requires confirmation at high power. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I can see the edge of the lymph node adjacent to adipose tissue. The bulk of the tissue consists of a dense sheet of small, dark lymphocytes. However, there is a distinct, well-demarcated nodule of different cells. These cells are larger, have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and irregularly shaped, vesicular nuclei. They are arranged in cohesive nests and glandular-like structures. This cluster of atypical epithelial cells within the lymphoid parenchyma is diagnostic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing a metastatic tumor deposit from a colorectal primary.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, the normal lymph node parenchyma is largely replaced by a malignant infiltrate. There are residual aggregates of small, dark lymphocytes, particularly at the bottom periphery, representing remnants of lymphoid follicles. The majority of the field is occupied by cohesive nests and poorly formed glands of atypical epithelial cells. These malignant cells are large, have pleomorphic nuclei with irregular contours, vesicular chromatin, and prominent nucleoli, and possess a moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm. This morphology is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is definitive for a lymph node positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the parenchyma of a lymph node characterized by numerous, prominent lymphoid follicles. These follicles have well-defined, pale-staining germinal centers surrounded by darker mantle zones. The cells within the germinal centers appear to be a mix of lymphocytes of varying sizes and tingible body macrophages, which is characteristic of a reactive process (follicular hyperplasia). The surrounding interfollicular areas are densely packed with small lymphocytes. I do not see any atypical glandular structures, nests of malignant cells, or desmoplastic reaction that would suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, the normal lymph node architecture is completely replaced by a malignant infiltrate. I see back-to-back, poorly-formed glands and solid nests of atypical epithelial cells. The tumor cells show significant nuclear pleomorphism, hyperchromasia, and irregular nuclear contours. There is evidence of glandular necrosis (so-called "dirty necrosis") which is characteristic of colorectal adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a lymph node positive for metastatic adenocarcinoma.
